claim: Most people who get COVID-19 recover from it
label: Supported
evidences: While most people infected with SARS-CoV-2 will recover, mortality increases with age and co-morbidity in those who develop severe illness.

claim: There are currently no drugs licensed for the treatment or prevention of COVID-19.
label: Supported
evidences: According to the WHO, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), there is currently no proven effective drug or vaccine for the treatment or prevention of SARS-CoV-2 infection.

claim: Catching COVID-19 DOES NOT mean you will have it for life.
label: Supported
evidences: The myth of ‘impurity’, of being tainted, made ‘untouchable’: ‘Catching the new coronavirus DOES NOT mean you will have it for life’, the myth makes the virus an event of a lifetime.

claim: Children can be infected with the virus that causes COVID-19 and can get sick with COVID-19.
label: Supported
evidences: Indeed, children can get sick and are an important vector of transmission of SARS-CoV-2 6,10 .

claim: If you have been in close contact with someone who has COVID-19, you should be tested, even if you do not have symptoms of COVID-19.
label: Supported
evidences: if you are a smoker or have been in contact with someone with covid, get tested.

claim: Adding pepper to your soup or other meals DOES NOT prevent or cure COVID-19
label: Supported
evidences: Many other common food insecurity coping strategies are also challenging amidst COVID-19 public health advisories and restrictions.

claim: The coronavirus disease is caused by a virus, not by bacteria.
label: Supported
evidences: Background: Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) is an infectious disease caused by a new virus.

claim: Coronaviruses typically survive longer and stay active longer at lower temperatures in a dry environment.
label: Supported
evidences: CoVs survive longer in the environment at lower temperatures and lower relative humidity.

claim: When travelling to countries/areas with active community transmission of COVID-19 virus, the public should avoid close contact with persons
label: Supported
evidences: Close contact with infected individuals (within six feet) through respiratory droplets (coughing/sneezing) landing in the mouths/noses of people nearby or inhaled through the lungs are the suspected mode of transmission of the virus between people.

claim: The seasonal influenza vaccine will not protect against COVID-19.
label: Supported
evidences: In particular, influenza vaccine did not affect seasonal coronavirus risk.

claim: COVID-19 symptoms are usually mild and flu-like.
label: Supported
evidences: Most patients affected by SARS-CoV-2 experience a flu-like illness with mild symptoms such as fever, cough, and some degree of dyspnea.

claim: COVID-19 can sometimes be spread by airborne transmission
label: Supported
evidences: Some infections can be spread by exposure to virus in small droplets and particles that can linger in the air for minutes to hours.

claim: Influenza (Flu) and COVID-19 are both contagious respiratory illnesses, but they are caused by different viruses.
label: Supported
evidences: Influenza is also a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses that infect upper respiratory tract, and sometimes the lungs;

claim: COVID-19 seems to spread more easily than flu.
label: Supported
evidences: Flu vaccinations make it more difficult for it to spread among the population because there are fewer options for it to transfer to the uninfected.

claim: Trouble breathing, persistent pain or pressure in the chest, new confusion, and inability to wake or stay awake are emergency warning signs for COVID-19.
label: Supported
evidences: The emergency warning signs of COVID-19 warranting seeking of medical attention includes trouble breathing, persistent pain or pressure in the chest, confusion or inability to arouse and bluish lips or face.

claim: Cases of reinfection with COVID-19 have been reported, but remain rare​.​
label: Supported
evidences: Rare cases of suspected COVID-19 “recurrence” or “reactivation” have been reported, including the description by Ye & Colleagues in this journal of 5 patients with suspected SARS COV 2 reactivation after home discharge

claim: People who are older are at higher risk of getting very sick from COVID-19.
label: Supported
evidences: The risk of severe COVID-19 if an individual becomes infected is known to be higher in older individuals and those with underlying health conditions.

claim: People of any age can get COVID-19, even healthy young adults and children.
label: Supported
evidences: COVID-19 was more prevalent among young people, but mostly affected the middle-aged and the old people.

claim: COVID-19 may cause loss of taste or smell, skin rash or discolouration of fingers or toes.
label: Supported
evidences: The COVID-19 patients suffer from several clinical symtoms including fever, dry cough, fatigue, headache, sore throat, loss of taste and smell, aches and pains, diarrhea, skin rashes and/or discoloration of fingers and toes.

claim: Surgical mask can prevent transmission of coronavirus.
label: Supported
evidences: Such transmission could be reduced by surgical mask usage, especially when masks were worn by infected individuals.

claim: People who use drugs may have underlying medical conditions that put them at increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19
label: Supported
evidences: The high prevalence of chronic conditions among PWUD, including respiratory diseases like asthma and COPD, may put them at increased risk of COVID-19 infection and severe disease

claim: COVID-19 can affect your nose, throat, lungs (respiratory tract); cause an asthma attack; and possibly lead to pneumonia and acute respiratory disease.
label: Supported
evidences: COVID-19 can affect your respiratory tract (nose, throat, lungs), cause an asthma attack, and possibly lead to pneumonia and acute respiratory disease", asthma may not be a potent risk factor .

claim: A person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or eyes.
label: Supported
evidences: it may be possible that a person contract COVID-19 by touching a surface that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes.

claim: Wearing a mask helps stop the spread of COVID-19 to others.
label: Supported
evidences: mandatory mask wearing by the public likely played an important role in stopping the spread of the disease.

claim: Spread happens when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks, and droplets from their mouth or nose are launched into the air and land in the mouths or noses of people nearby.
label: Supported
evidences: However, the disease is thought to spread i) mainly from person-to-person, who are in close contact with one another (within about 2 m) ii) through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs, sneezes or talks iii) which can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs

claim: COVID-19 can cause symptoms that can last for weeks or even months after recovery.
label: Supported
evidences: Smell disruption improved in the remaining patents although continue after three months suggesting that recovery will be more difficult the longer the symptom lasts.

claim: If soap and water are not available, use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol to prevent COVID-19.
label: Supported
evidences: Third, if soap and water are not available, alcohol-based hand sanitizer (at least 60% alcohol) can be rubbed into hands for 20 s.

claim: Social distancing is important to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
label: Supported
evidences: For preventing the spread of epidemics such as the coronavirus disease COVID-19, social distancing and the isolation of infected persons are crucial.

claim: COVID-19 most commonly spreads during close contact.
label: Supported
evidences: The COVID-19 is mainly transmitted through respiratory droplets and close contact.

claim: COVID-19 spreads less commonly through contact with contaminated surfaces.
label: Supported
evidences: There is limited data that indicates that COVID-19 may also spread through indirect contact with contaminated environments and aerosols.
